Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: MRS. ESTHER MAUD GOLDSMITH
Present Address: HOOSIER, SASK.
Pioneer Address: WHITEWOOD, SASK.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1897

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experiences and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your cooperation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About 8.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? One.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? About once a week.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mostly Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Sometimes invited but always welcome.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Without a meal.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Very seldom got away without a meal.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Never heard the term "potluck" used. Usually, you must stay for dinner or supper.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Almost always tea. Sometimes lemonade, never any alcoholic beverages.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? The whole family went at courthouse.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? We had many bees, both inside and out.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. Remember one bee, when long, father had stepped down, so the neighbors being gathered to support his crops. Also, these same men took part in nights, so help each other to relieve some of the work, so another, sometimes then.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

All the dances were in homes. Some were taken over one left out, even though the house were small. Different kinds of games were played including parlor games.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Yes, they gradually died out. Afterwards schools, balls were built.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Yes, a plan was followed.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially, etc.?

We got into a bit of that after our school days. In the small town there was the afternoon for calling and calling cards.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

The neighbors all gathered together with horns, tin lids, & anything that would make a lot of noise, then proceeded to the home of the bridegroom. When they would be invited and have a meal, they would have a real laugh.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

After the automobile came things were changed. Baseball sports were organized. Sports days were held in all the small towns so there was not so much neighborhood visiting.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The Grain Growers.

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

It was a forerunner of the Grain Growers throughout the farmers' co-operative societies such as the Farmers' Co-operative Association.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

It came from the old Grange which was organized about 1892.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Most of them!

How many women belonged? How often did it meet?

One woman was a member along with her husband.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Buying of goods sometimes a social time lunch.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not at that time

When was it organized? After I was married in 1911

Approximately how many women belonged to it? About 40

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

We built, furnished a hall. Playing for money, putting on social affairs. We took charge of all the social activities in the district. Our hall to this day is very useful for all kinds of meetings & social affairs.

Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

An agricultural society was organized in 1913. Most of the people took part in it. A hall was built. This carried on successfully until the hard years of the 1930s when we had to disband. Since then the building has been used as a meeting place for women and high school students.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? Taking advantage, Putting on dances, Plays, Amateur contests.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

In the homes of members, hall after it was built, before that in the different houses.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Not much before 1914.

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

Bally, Wading in the slough, Riding their ponies.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?

Skipping rope, some ball, some paddling in slough's.

PI. NICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. July 1892.

26. Who organized it? The Orange Lodge.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? For the entire community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? No.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Games, races, a fine band, plenty of sewing for the children.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? There was a general lunch. Long tables under the trees, everybody sat down.

31. What did you have to eat and drink? Sandwiches, pies, cakes, cookies, "hot salads," lots of tea, lemonade.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? It started as early in the day as people could get there and lasted until sundown.

33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

The arrangements were thoughtful, elegant. The leader riding a white horse. There were speeches by different members and a very good band. People sang hymns even in the rain. Everyone was very friendly.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

Some years later there were school picnics but on a smaller scale. Always held in holiday times. Games were always plenty of good races. Very sociable but not all standing like the Orange Lodge picnics.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Since cars became common, the picnics are becoming a thing of the past. Sports days, a standard thing taken over by the schools. Everyone looks forward to them.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Track races, high jumping, long jumping, wrestling, stone throwing. Very popular among everyone. Everyone looked forward to them.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Baseball league. Played at many local sports days. Teams from all towns in the district.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

About 1913 it was used mostly by the children attending our Consolidated School.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

In 1914, used for curling. Most of the men, women, and the district taking part, also high school pupils.

50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started? In the early years of 1930.

Who started it? The Homemakers Club.

Is it still in existence? No.

If not, when was it discontinued, and why? After times became better, people could afford newspapers and magazines belonging to Reading Clubs. All the books collected in the Community Library before the library was returned to the owners.

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

It was kept in the Homemakers Hall, and certain days were set to exchange the books. Members of the club took turns in acting as Librarian. Everyone who cared about reading used it.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

The first papers I can remember were the Family Herald, the Northwest Farmer.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

We later dropped the Family Herald as it took so long to come from Montreal. Its place was the Winnipeg Free Press.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes, and also the children's paper, Hilda.

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

It must have been about 1894, they were sent to us through the mail.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

As a child, I was very fond of reading and having no libraries, I often read over several times the little books even the school readers.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

My hobby was growing things, gardening of all kinds. I planted and took care of most of the trees on our farm. Lots of work on the wild prairie.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

In the Pioneer days of the Hoosier community, The Homemakers Club was the head of all social activities. After building our hall we made good use of it, putting on dances, plays, musical concerts, Box socials, debates, etc. The proceeds from these affairs soon paid for the Hall's furnishing.

"The pioneer days of this town were the head of all. Social activities. Often building our hall was a good use of it, putting on dances, plays, musical concerts, band societies, blebaters, etc. The proceeds from these affairs, some paid for the hall, some for the blebaters."
